Fun Fact

Over 2000 event invitations have been created in the few months since launch!

Designing and developing a tool to allow TED's global Circles community of over 10,000 participants to create and share event invitations

The key user delight comes at seeing a "tangible", digital invitation being created as they enter event information into a more traditional form.

The Challenge

TED Circles is a new but growing global community of learners who get together in small pods to gain new perspectives. In essence, they are book clubs around TED talks. Similar to TEDx, TED Circles has a simple "licensing" model where TED provides its brand to facilitate the creativity of local "Hosts". Given this flexible structure, Hosts will sometimes operate outside of TED's awareness, creating events opaque to us. The Circles team came to me with a need to incentivize Hosts to schedule their events through TED, allowing us to have a better sense of the success of the group, connect Circles in the same country, and provide customer support.

The Approach

The existing solution was a Google Form that Hosts filled out before each event. It functioned well, but didn't provide any clear value to the Hosts, so was often unused. Early on, I had a design principle of creating win-win scenarios in which Hosts AND TED benefit from creating events in our ecosystem. Tactically, this meant: Any time you ask someone to take the time to fill in some information, make sure they're getting something in return.

Key principles for the tool

In order to achieve some of the goals above, I worked with the Circles team to brainstorm ways to support the hosts. We landed on the creation of an invitation â€“ something visually appealing that they could send to their friends. It'd make them look good

Early mock to convey how form inputs map to stylized text on an invitation using a two-panel layout.

Tech Stack ft. Airtable

Since TED Circles was a new and small team, their internal processes were lean and hands-on. Their desire to iterate the tool and community quickly led to a technological decision to create a new stack outside of the normal, heavy TED.com infra. Instead of involving 2-3 engineers to create custom APIs and a database admin panel, I adapted a tool they were already using, Airtable, into our stack. Although unconventional, we use Airtable as the sole database for Circles events. This allowed them to create email automations and other fancy interactions without touching a messy backend. So, the tool uses the Airtable JS API along with Netlify Functions to hide the API keys. Netlify also hosts our static site.

Key features

Here are a few features that were built over 1-2 months of in-the-wild testing.

Auto-populated calendar invites

Create and populate calendar invites for Hosts.

Unique invite urls

Create a unique invitation URL for Hosts to share as well as sample "share text"

Invitation page

Invitation page that updates as a Host updates event info

Date & time pickers

Many browsers do not have native date and time pickers. So, I had to use external libraries to catch and test the many edge cases of these inputs.

Tangible invitations, digitally

Using tilt.js, I tried to give the invitations a sense of physicallity.

Wrapping up

The TED Circles community is an iterative experiment that'll grow over time - and such, that has been my development approach. The Event Generator site was announced at the 1-year-anniversary celebration of the community. Metrics aside, people expressed deep gratitude in having such thought and care taken to something that they used often. Over 2000 event invitations were created in the few months after launch. Early success led to a large round of QA testing and bug fixes. Up next, we're working on creating a dashboard for Hosts to view and manage all their events in one place.
